results.title: Yanmeeyarr
results.credit_line:
Vicki Couzens

Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens

Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel

Commissioned by ACMI and co-created with Jeph Neale and Hilary Jackman
results.material_description:
Acrylic paint, carved and hand-polished acrylic lens.
Laser cut mirror finish and etched stainless steel.
results.brief_description: In Yanmeeyarr, Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_primary.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Light and shadow have been a powerful storytelling tool long before they were the basis for the moving image. For thousands of generations in Australia, First Peoples storytelling has harnessed the movement of the world and play of light: the special glow of sunset to catch the movement of dancing feet, the flickering campfire as tales are told in the night, the story of stars and constellations told in the Dreaming.

In this multi-part artwork Gunditjmara artist Vicki Couzens references how ochre markings on the body capture and reflect light during ceremony, creating a centuries-spanning connection between traditional First Peoples storytelling and the contemporary moving image.

“Where does moving image originate? Shadow and light, elemental movement and action; see figures in formation, ceremony in the circle, moving, in rhythm, in rhyme with the heartbeat, sunlight, moon shadow, Yanmeeyarr… flickering in firelight. Dancers painted and adorned, in corroboree, in ceremony, telling story through the dance. The viewer in movement and reflection becomes part of the dance, as the figures become animated. Yanmeeyarr, flickering in the firelight, is reflected in the present; the viewer and the new technologies of today, become part of the work and the ongoing past-present-future of our storytelling continuum.” – Vicki Couzens

Yanmeeyarr is generously supported by the Sidney Myer Fund

results.title: Making of Bush Mechanics
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.
results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:

results.title: Landscape as Character
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_primary.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_primary.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. results.title: VFX in Overwatch
results.brief_description: A look at the use of VFX in Blizzard Entertainment’s hit videogame Overwatch.

constellations_primary.name: Blizzard, Bowie and the Bonets
constellations_primary.description: Overwatch is the beginning of some surprising connections in this Constellation that explores videogame movies, cartoons, and music docos and shows.

results.description: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of, to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it’s success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game’s developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren’t just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.
description_for_label: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of, to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it’s success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game’s developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren’t just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.
